item.title: Setting up machine learning development environment
item.description:
I decided to write this after facing the surprisingly annoying process of installing various packages for machine learning purposes.

Let’s start from the beginning. Create an environment on anaconda:

conda create -n pytorch-env python=3

Switch to the pytorch-env environment:

conda activate pytorch-env

Install PyTorch according to the official documentation. Notice that it includes cpuonly instead of cudatoolkit. This means that there will be no CUDA support, which is intentional because I’m doing this in a VM.

conda install pytorch torchvision torchaudio cpuonly -c pytorch

Install some other packages commonly used for ML:

conda install opencv matplotlib jupyterlab nb_conda

This is the point where I got this message:

Solving environment: -
Found conflicts! Looking for incompatible packages.
This can take several minutes.  Press CTRL-C to abort.

This took a really long time to finish, with failures on top of that. Some suggestions like updating packages (conda update --all) and allowing downgrades (conda config --set allow_conda_downgrades true) didn’t help at all.

Turns out the solution is quite simple, just install from pytorch channel as well:

conda install -c pytorch opencv matplotlib jupyterlab nb_conda

I saw some packages downgraded when I did that:

  certifi                          2020.12.5-py38h06a4308_0 --> 2020.12.5-py37h06a4308_0
  mkl-service                          2.3.0-py38he904b0f_0 --> 2.3.0-py37he8ac12f_0
  mkl_fft                              1.2.1-py38h54f3939_0 --> 1.2.1-py37h54f3939_0
  mkl_random                           1.1.1-py38h0573a6f_0 --> 1.1.1-py37h0573a6f_0
  ninja                               1.10.2-py38hff7bd54_0 --> 1.10.2-py37hff7bd54_0
  numpy                               1.19.2-py38h54aff64_0 --> 1.19.2-py37h54aff64_0
  numpy-base                          1.19.2-py38hfa32c7d_0 --> 1.19.2-py37hfa32c7d_0
  pillow                               8.1.0-py38he98fc37_0 --> 8.1.0-py37he98fc37_0
  pip                                 21.0.1-py38h06a4308_0 --> 21.0.1-py37h06a4308_0
  python                                   3.8.5-h7579374_1 --> 3.7.9-h7579374_0
  pytorch                                 1.7.1-py3.8_cpu_0 --> 1.7.1-py3.7_cpu_0
  setuptools                          52.0.0-py38h06a4308_0 --> 52.0.0-py37h06a4308_0
  six                                 1.15.0-py38h06a4308_0 --> 1.15.0-py37h06a4308_0
  torchaudio                                     0.7.2-py38 --> 0.7.2-py37
  torchvision                                0.8.2-py38_cpu --> 0.8.2-py37_cpu

My guess is that the default channel (and conda-forge too, I tried) didn’t have the older versions of some packages installed through pytorch in the earlier step, so conda just gave up instead.

item.title: Synology Router Manager broken in Firefox
item.description:
Synology Router Manager (SRM) is the name of web interface to manage your Synology Router RT2600ac device. For me, my SRM address is configured as http://router.synology.com:8000/webman/index.cgi.

Recently, when I opened it on Firefox, I got an error page saying something like this:

An error occurred during a connection to router.synology.com:8000. PR_END_OF_FILE_ERROR

I was able to open it just fine on Chrome, so it seemed that Firefox screwed up somewhere.

Upon further examination, I noticed that on Firefox, I was redirected to HTTPS, so I was actually visiting https://router.synology.com:8000/webman/index.cgi.

I confirmed that the Automatically redirect HTTP connections to HTTPS and Enable HSTS checkboxes in SRM Control Panel were both NOT checked, so why was this happening?

Turns out, there is a totally-not-new concept of HSTS preloading, apparently started in Chrome, but Firefox has followed suit. Taking a look at the list preloaded by Firefox (available here, look for nsSTSPreloadList.inc), seems like synology.com is included in the list.

So, maybe Firefox considers router.synology.com:8000 the same as synology.com? Anyway, the fix is clear:

  • Open up about:config
  • Find network.stricttransportsecurity.preloadlist
  • Flip it to false

Done! Shamelessly stolen from this StackOverflow answer.

Note: This was Firefox 76.0.1 and Chrome 81.0.4044.138 respectively.

item.title: Arch Linux broken desktop environment in VirtualBox
item.description:
I updated my Arch VM with the usual command:

pacman -Syu

Then, upon rebooting the VM, after logging-in again, the desktop environment would only show a black screen. I was still able to bring up tty2 with Ctrl + Alt + F2, so it seemed like other than the desktop environment, the VM was running just fine.

After some debugging, I suspected that virtualbox-guest-utils package was the culprit. Checking through the update log, it seemed like that package was indeed updated:

cat /var/log/pacman.log
...
[2020-05-17T21:21:34+0900] [ALPM] upgraded xorg-bdftopcf (1.1-1 -> 1.1-2)
[2020-05-17T21:21:34+0900] [ALPM] upgraded ttf-hack (3.003-1 -> 3.003-2)
[2020-05-17T21:21:34+0900] [ALPM] upgraded virtualbox-guest-utils (6.1.6-1 -> 6.1.8-1)
[2020-05-17T21:21:34+0900] [ALPM] upgraded vlc (3.0.8-13 -> 3.0.10-1)
[2020-05-17T21:21:34+0900] [ALPM] upgraded vte-common (0.60.1-1 -> 0.60.2-2)
...

I downgraded back to 6.1.6-1 and things are now good again:

sudo pacman -U https://archive.archlinux.org/packages/v/virtualbox-guest-utils/virtualbox-guest-utils-6.1.6-1-x86_64.pkg.tar.zst

The worst thing about this was that there was no clipboard sharing at the time (because all GUIs were broken), so I had to type the whole URL on the terminal myself :(
